div.head: The Thousand Buddhas of the Fortunate Kalpa
div.p: Various origin stories
A. The story comes in the fifth chapter of Toh 47, Tathāgatācintyaguhyanirdeśa, F.117.b – 125.b:
Eon “Beautifully Illuminating” (mdzes par snang ba)
Universe “Fully Adorned” (rnam par brgyan pa)
Buddha “King Set with Jewels of Infinite Qualities” (yon tan mtha’ yas rin chen sna tshogs bkod pa’i rgyal po)
Intermediate 4-continent world “Beautifully Illuminating” (mdzes par snang ba)
Central city and palace: “The Pure” (rnam par dag pa can)
King Dhṛtarāṣṭra (yul ’khor srung) has 700,000 queens (all bodhisattvas) and 1,000 sons (bu stong du tshang ba).
Two are born miraculously, Dharma Mind (chos sems pa) and Dharmamati (chos kyi blo gros) and receive teaching on the nature of phenomena.
The king puts all the names of his sons in a precious vase and makes offerings for seven days, then pulls out names.

item.p: 1. Prince Pure Intelligence (gzhon nu rnam par dag pa’i blo gros), who is predicted to be Krakucchanda.
2. Victorious Army (gzhon nu rnam par rgyal ba’i sde) – Kanakamuni
…and so forth up to 21 Tathāgatas (note that after 6, seng ge, the names are not the same as in the Bhadrakalpika).

div.p: last Matyananta (thams cad kyi tha chungs ] blo gros mtha’ yas) – Adhimukta (mos pa)
chos sems pa vows to become Vajrapāṇi for all of them, and Dharmamati will request all of them to turn the wheel of Dharma, as Mahābrahmā.
Dhṛtarāstra was previous life of Buddha Dīpaṃkara.

This is mentioned in the “empowerment of the thousand buddhas” for Ratnalingpa’s thugs rje chen po gsang ba ’dus pa (Rin chen gter mdzod new Shechen edition vol. ’a, p. 291) which lists their names, ending in snang mdzad (Roca) rather than Adhimukta.

B. In Toh 94, Bhadrakalpika -- beginning of 2nd chapter (F.17.a-b), a Dharmabhāṇaka called rin po che’i lus mtha’ yas par grags pa spyod pa’i mdzod, teaches the teachings (in particular the samādhi being described in this sūtra) of the Buddha gser sdug mdzes pa rnam par nges pa’i ’od kyi gzi brjid kyi rgyal po to a cakravartin king called skye bo mang po mngon par dga’ zhing mya ngan med pa’i nga ro. The Dharmabhāṇaka, the King, the king’s 1,000 sons, and a whole group of attendants then practise and accumulate virtue for 80 kalpas.

The Dharmabhāṇaka was none other than Amitāyus in a previous life; the King becomes Akṣobhya; and the 1,000 princes become the 1,000 buddhas of the Fortunate Eon. These are listed by name from F.86b – 101.b.
see Skilling ARIRIAB XIII (2010)

C. Also comes in the final chapter of Toh 176,
Vimalakīrtinirdeśa , 12.6-18

But in this version the origin takes place in an eon called Vicaraṇa, a universe called Mahāvyūha, featuring a buddha Bhaiṣajyarāja and King Ratnacchattra, one of whose sons Candracchattra, who became the next buddha after Bhaiṣajyarāja and taught for ten short eons.

Ratnacchattra was a previous life of the Tathāgata Ratnārcis (buddha of a western buddhafield acc to PP); the thousand sons, of the buddhas of the Fortunate Eon; and in particular Candracchattra, of Śākyamuni.
The last buddha is mentioned as Roca (snang mdzad).
